unnormalised: Shopping in India has changed, hasn’t it? Remember the days when bargaining was the norm? You'd go to Linking Road in Mumbai or Sarojini Nagar in Delhi and haggle for everything. A shirt priced at Rs. 800 could easily be yours for Rs. 500 if you were good at it. Now, with online shopping, things are different. While the thrill of bargaining is missed, the convenience is undeniable.
normalised: Shopping in India has changed, hasn't it? Remember the days when bargaining was the norm? You'd go to Linking Road in Mumbai or Sarojini Nagar in Delhi and haggle for everything. A shirt priced at rupee eight hundred could easily be yours for rupee five hundred if you were good at it. Now, with online shopping, things are different. While the thrill of bargaining is missed, the convenience is undeniable.

unnormalised: E-commerce sites have exploded. My mother, who used to swear by her local market, now buys groceries online. She says, "Why go all the way when BigBasket delivers it for Rs. 50?" And the sales! Flipkart’s Big Billion Days and Amazon’s Great Indian Festival…it's madness! You can snag a TV for 40% off or a new phone with a Rs. 10,000 exchange offer. It’s tempting, isn’t it?

It's tempting, isn't it?

unnormalised: Even offline retailers are getting in on the act. D-Mart, for example, often has items cheaper than what you'd find online, but sometimes you will find the exact same item for a price that varies by even Rs. 20. They’re also running more promotions. "Buy 2 Get 1 Free" is plastered everywhere. Pantaloons offers a 50% discount on select items every now and then, pulling in crowds like before.

unnormalised: But is it really cheaper? Sometimes, I wonder. Those “limited-time” deals are designed to make you panic-buy. And delivery charges? They can add up! Rs. 99 here, Rs. 49 there… suddenly your "bargain" isn't such a bargain anymore. Plus, those subscription services like Amazon Prime, costing Rs. 1499 per year, can influence your buying decisions.

Plus, those subscription services like Amazon Prime, costing rupee one thousand four hundred and ninety nine per year, can influence your buying decisions.

unnormalised: Ultimately, whether you’re shopping for a saree for Rs. 2500 or a new washing machine for Rs. 15000, it pays to compare prices. Don’t just jump on the first deal you see. A little bit of research can save you a lot of money. After all, that’s how we’ve always done it in India, right? A savvy shopper is a happy shopper!
